title: If the big bang created everything, is it possible that it also created logic and mathematics? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. The Big Bang may or may not have created every physical thing, but it had and has no part in creating conceptual things such as: BlueConnectedSolidAboveCompactIrrationalInfinitesimalThe excluded middleand so on. Mathematics and Logic are nothing but conceptual things. They are essentially independent of the universe except, perhaps, a universe is required for conscious beings to dream up concepts. (The concepts may have physical reality in the brains of the conscious being, but those are representations of the concepts and not the concepts themselves.) Incidentally, very solid physical things such as rocks and tables are actually concepts as well. The reality that exists is some swirl of quantum fields whose interactions we describe as a "rock" or a "table". Mind you, if a rock hits you on the head I am happy to accept that it "really exists" [math]\ddot\smallsmile[/math]

The Big Bang isn’t the kind of thing that “creates” anything. It just happened (or not). Nobody is even able to describe the Big Bang itself, if any. The Big Bang itself could be the effect of something else. At best, we can think of logic as a byproduct of billions of years of natural selection over the entire biosphere on Earth. Presumably, the Earth itself is distant effect of the Big Bang, so logic can be regarded also as an effect of the Big Bang. Same thing for mathematics. However, this is all highly speculative. The Big Bang is merely the most plausible scenario given the empirical evidence available. A pinch of salt is required here.

I think we have to accept that the Big Bang kick started 'our' universe (whether it was the first time round or not). Now, did that include logic and mathematics? According to some Multiverse Theories 'anything that can happen does happen'. I cannot think of a reason why this should not include alternative 'logic' and alternative 'mathematics'. I believe that both were discovered rather than created so they were an inherent part of everything from the beginning. From my viewpoint I cannot comprehend an alternative 'logic' or an alternative 'mathematics' but we should not allow our prejudices to cloud our science 'theory' judgment.

If the big bang created everything, is it possible that it also created logic and mathematics? If the big bang created everything, then it created everything, including logic, mathematics, you, me and the gatepost. But it did not create everything. It was only the starting point from which everything evolved.

If you have studied mathematics and set theory, Universe is the universal set. All the tools and knowledge we have are inside it. When we see a straight line and an equation describing it, it falls inside of this universal set.

No. Mathematics isn’t physically real: it’s abstract. Physical conditions can’t change the digits of Pi or in-prove Fermat’s Theorem. All different physics can do is need different logic and mathematics for its description.
Logic and mathematics and science were created by human beings. Over a long period, and with great opposition from the rest of human society at any given time.
You already answered your question. If something created everything, then it created everything. Tautology, true, and obvious.
It didn't “create” mathematics. Maths is a tool to express certain aspects of logic to help us understand physical (and abstract) matters.
It created a universe where logic and mathematics are miraculously powerful in understanding the universe.
